title: Prime Factorization Tree Builder
description: Interactive tool for building factor trees to find prime factorization of composite numbers through step-by-step visual construction.
subject: Mathematics
learningObjectives: Build factor trees to decompose composite numbers into prime factors
Identify and distinguish between prime and composite numbers
Understand that prime factorization is unique for each number (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic)
Apply divisibility rules to find factors efficiently
Express numbers in prime factorization form using exponential notation
bloomLevels: Remember: Recall prime numbers and divisibility rules
Understand: Explain the relationship between factors and prime factorization
Apply: Use divisibility rules to factor numbers systematically
Analyze: Compare different factorization paths leading to same result
Evaluate: Verify completeness and correctness of factorization
Create: Build complete factor trees for any composite number
prerequisites: Familiarity with prime and composite numbers
author: Claude (Anthropic AI)

controls.numberInput: Enter a number between 4 and 200 to factor
controls.randomNumber: Generate a random composite number at selected difficulty
controls.giveHint: Highlight a composite number and suggest divisibility rule
controls.showAnswer: Display the complete factorization tree with all prime factors
controls.clickNode: Click on blue (composite) nodes to enter two factors
controls.submitFactors: Validate and add factors to the tree

visualElements.edges: Lines connecting parent numbers to their factors
visualElements.primeList: Reference list of prime numbers up to 47
visualElements.divisibilityRules: Quick reference for divisibility by 2, 3, and 5

features: Show answer feature for complete factorization
pedagogicalApproach: Scaffolding through hints and reference materials
assessmentOpportunities: Predict prime factorization before building tree
Explain why different trees yield same factorization
commonMisconceptions: Using 1 as a factor (prevented by validation)
Stopping factorization before reaching primes (visual feedback)
Confusion about prime vs composite (color coding)
extensions: Compare different factorization paths for same number
Find GCF and LCM using prime factorizations
Explore perfect squares and their symmetric trees
Apply to finding square roots of perfect squares

technicalDetails.animations: shake on error, celebration on completion
technicalDetails.dataStructure: tree represented as nodes and edges
